School Management System (Tkinter)

gui.tkinter_app_db module

author:

tamara fakih

project:

ece/eece435l – software tools lab (fall 2025–2026)

version:

1.0.0

license:

educational / course use

why this file exists (short honest note)

documentation gets ignored when deadlines are close, but we still need to understand our own code later. so i’m adding module docs in sphinx style now, and i’ll let sphinx build a clean website from it.

what this module wires together

  • tkinter/ttk ui (tabs for students, instructors, courses, relations, records/search, json/io)

  • sqlite repository adapter (single instance), with basic validators and json helpers

  • a light aub-ish theme so the tables don’t look painful

how i run it
>>> python -m src.gui.tkinter_app_db
(or run the file directly if imports resolve)
notes

this is lab-level code: clarity > clever tricks. i keep the sql readable and the handlers explicit.

class App[source]

Bases: Tk

a tkinter main window for the small school management system. not trying to be super abstract; this is basically the gui shell that wires the db repo + validators + json helpers into tabs.

Parameters:

args (None) – nothing special for now (no external args expected)

Variables:

  • repo (SQLiteRepository) – sqlite repository the whole app uses to talk to the db

  • logo_img (tkinter.PhotoImage or None) – optional app logo if found on disk, otherwise None (no problem)

  • tree_students (ttk.Treeview) – table widget that lists students (id, name, age, email, courses)

  • tree_instructors (ttk.Treeview) – table widget for instructors

  • tree_courses (ttk.Treeview) – table widget for courses

  • rec_students (dict) – small dict with a frame and a tree for the search view (students)

  • rec_instructors (dict) – same idea as above but for instructors

  • rec_courses (dict) – same idea as above but for courses

Notes:

tabs are: students / instructors / courses / register-assign / records-search / json. theme is mild aub-ish. i keep handlers explicit and sql readable because… future me will thank me.

sets up the main window and the bare essentials: title/size/scaling, a small ttk theme, opens the sqlite repo, tries to load a logo if available, builds all tabs, then refreshes so tables don’t look empty. kind of the boot sequence, nothing too dramatic.

Returns:

nothing; just prepares ui + state

Return type:

None

Raises:

RuntimeError – if tkinter/init goes really wrong or repo setup bubbles a hard error (rare)

__init__() → None[source]

sets up the main window and the bare essentials: title/size/scaling, a small ttk theme, opens the sqlite repo, tries to load a logo if available, builds all tabs, then refreshes so tables don’t look empty. kind of the boot sequence, nothing too dramatic.

Returns:

nothing; just prepares ui + state

Return type:

None

Raises:

RuntimeError – if tkinter/init goes really wrong or repo setup bubbles a hard error (rare)

_add_header(parent: Widget, title: str) → None[source]

adds a tiny header bar to a container: optional logo on the left and the given title next to it. keeps spacing light and lets the title stretch so it aligns nicely.

Parameters:

  • parent (tkinter.Widget) – the tk/ttk container where the header should be placed

  • title (str) – the text to show as the section title

Returns:

nothing; it just builds and grids the header widgets

Return type:

None

Notes:

if logo_img is None we just render the text label, no problem.

_build_courses_tab() → None[source]

builds the “courses” page: header, a form for course id / name / optional instructor id, a few action buttons, and the table that lists courses with their instructor (if any) and enrolled students. layout mirrors the other tabs on purpose.

Returns:

nothing; just creates widgets and wires the selection handler

Return type:

None

Notes:

selecting a row fills the form so editing is quicker; instructor field can stay empty.

_build_instructors_tab() → None[source]

builds the whole “instructors” page: header, a small form for id/name/age/email, action buttons (add/update, delete, clear), and the table that lists instructors plus the courses they own. layout mirrors the students tab so it feels consistent.

Returns:

nothing; it just creates widgets and hooks up the selection handler

Return type:

None

Notes:

clicking a row fills the form for quick edits; columns are sized to stay readable.

_build_io_tab() → None[source]

builds the “save / load json” page (plus backup and csv export). it’s basically the utility corner: export/import json using the existing layer, make a sqlite backup, and dump students/instructors/courses to csv.

Returns:

nothing; just creates buttons/labels/separators and wires handlers

Return type:

None

Notes:

the db itself isn’t cleared here; “clear all” only resets views/forms. backup writes a copy to a path you choose.

_build_records_tab() → None[source]

builds the “records & search” page: a tiny search bar + scope dropdown on top, and three read-only tables below (students, instructors, courses). pretty much a dashboard.

Returns:

nothing; it just creates widgets and wires the buttons

Return type:

None

Notes:

apply triggers filtered queries; clear resets scope to “All” and empties the search box.

_build_relations_tab() → None[source]

builds the “register & assign” page. it’s a tiny form with two entries (student id, course id) and one button to register the student into the course. kept minimal on purpose.

Returns:

nothing; just creates widgets and hooks the register button

Return type:

None

Notes:

validation/actual linking happens in _on_register_student; this tab is just the ui shell.

_build_students_tab() → None[source]

builds the whole “students” page: header, a small form to add/edit a student (id, name, age, email), action buttons, and the table that lists students with their registered courses. layout is simple: form on top, table below.

Returns:

nothing; it just creates widgets and wires basic events

Return type:

None

Notes:

the table binds selection so i can click a row and the form fills up for quick edits.

_build_ui() → None[source]

builds the main notebook ui: creates the tabs (students, instructors, courses, register/assign, records/search, json) and mounts them on the window. then it calls the per-tab builders to fill each page. straightforward layout, no tricks.

Returns:

nothing; just mutates the window by adding widgets

Return type:

None

Notes:

grid config lets the notebook stretch; tabs are created first then populated, which keeps the flow easier to follow when reading the code.

_clear_course_form() → None[source]

clears the course form inputs (id, name, instructor id) and removes any selection from the courses table, so i can start clean before adding/editing.

Returns:

nothing; just resets entries + selection

Return type:

None

_clear_instructor_form() → None[source]

clears the instructor form inputs and drops any current selection in the table, so i can start clean before adding or editing.

Returns:

nothing; just resets entries + selection

Return type:

None

_clear_student_form() → None[source]

clears the student form fields and drops any table selection, so i start fresh. useful after add/update, or if i just want to reset before typing.

Returns:

nothing; just mutates entry widgets + selection

Return type:

None

_confirm(msg: str) → bool[source]

shows a yes/no confirm dialog with the given message. handy so i don’t rewrite the full messagebox.askyesno every time.

Parameters:

msg (str) – the question or warning text to show

Returns:

True if user clicked yes, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

_error(msg: str) → None[source]

small helper to pop up an error dialog with a given message. saves me from writing the full messagebox call every time.

Parameters:

msg (str) – the text to show inside the error box

Returns:

nothing; it just shows the dialog

Return type:

None

_fill_tree(tree: tkinter.ttk.Treeview, rows: Iterable[dict], order: Iterable[str]) → None[source]

clears a treeview and refills it from a list of row dicts, using the given key order. i also tag rows as odd/even for a light zebra effect.

Parameters:

  • tree (ttk.Treeview) – the treeview to write into

  • rows (Iterable[dict]) – iterable of dicts holding the data

  • order (Iterable[str]) – keys to pull from each row (and in this column order)

Returns:

nothing; it just repopulates the widget

Return type:

None

Notes:

values get cast to str before insert, so the table stays consistent.

_info(msg: str) → None[source]

quick helper for showing an info dialog, so i don’t repeat the long messagebox line each time. mostly for confirmations or status messages.

Parameters:

msg (str) – the text content to display in the info window

Returns:

nothing; just opens a simple ok dialog

Return type:

None

_load_logo()[source]

tries to load a small logo from a few usual places; if it exists, i scale it down to around 320px width so it doesn’t take over the header, then return it. if loading complains, i just skip it and move on.

Returns:

photo image you can drop in a ttk.Label, or None if not found/failed

Return type:

tkinter.PhotoImage or None

Notes:

checks these paths (in order): ‘logo.png’, ‘data/logo.png’, ‘assets/logo.png’, ‘resources/logo.png’

_make_tree(parent, cols, widths)[source]

small helper that builds a treeview inside a frame with a vertical scrollbar. i pass the columns and their widths, it returns a tiny dict so i can grid the frame and keep a handle on the tree.

Parameters:

  • parent (tkinter.Widget) – the container where this frame (with the tree) will live

  • cols (list or tuple) – column names to create in the tree (shown as headings)

  • widths (list or tuple) – pixel widths for each column (same order as cols)

Returns:

a dict with {“frame”: the outer frame, “tree”: the ttk.Treeview}

Return type:

dict

Notes:

headings get cased with .capitalize(); rows are added elsewhere via _fill_tree.

_on_add_or_update_course() → None[source]

saves a course from the form: i validate id/name first, then try to insert; if it already exists i update it instead (including optional instructor id). after that i refresh the ui and show a small info message.

Returns:

nothing; writes to the db and refreshes tables

Return type:

None

Raises:

none here; validation errors go to dialogs and insert→update is handled inside

Notes:

instructor id can be empty; when present i normalize it (same for course id/name).

_on_add_or_update_instructor() → None[source]

saves an instructor from the form: validate fields first, try to insert, and if the id already exists then i just update it. afterwards i refresh the tables and show a small info toast so it feels responsive.

Returns:

nothing; mutates the db and refreshes the ui

Return type:

None

Raises:

none here; validation errors are shown in dialogs and insert→update is handled

Notes:

i normalize id/name/email before writing, and cast age to int after checking it’s non-negative.

_on_add_or_update_student() → None[source]

handles saving a student from the form: i validate fields first, then try to insert; if the id already exists i just update instead. finally i refresh the tables and show a small info message so it feels responsive.

Returns:

nothing; updates the db and refreshes the ui

Return type:

None

Raises:

none here on purpose; validation errors show as dialogs and the insert→update path is handled

Notes:

validation uses the helpers (id/name/age/email). ids/emails/names are normalized before db ops.

_on_apply_search() → None[source]

applies the search: grabs the text + scope, runs simple like-based queries, and fills only the trees that match the chosen scope. others get cleared.

Returns:

nothing; just updates the three result tables

Return type:

None

Notes:

scope can be “All”, “Students”, “Instructors”, or “Courses”. empty query means “show all”.

_on_backup_db() → None[source]

makes a sqlite backup file with a timestamped name. i open a save dialog, then ask the repo to write a copy there. if it works i show the path, if not i show the error.

Returns:

nothing; just writes a backup file if you confirm a path

Return type:

None

Raises:

none directly here; any repo/file issue is caught and shown as an error dialog

Notes:

default filename looks like db-backup-YYYYMMDD-HHMMSS.sqlite so it’s easy to sort.

_on_clear_search() → None[source]

clears the search box and resets scope to “All”, then reloads the records view. basically a quick reset to see everything again.

Returns:

nothing; just resets inputs and repopulates tables

Return type:

None

_on_clear_ui() → None[source]

clears the ui state (tables/forms) after a quick confirm. the database stays as-is, this is just a visual reset so i can start clean.

Returns:

nothing; just refreshes all views

Return type:

None

_on_delete_selected_course() → None[source]

deletes the selected course after a quick confirm. if i say yes, the course goes away and any links to students/instructor are removed too. then i refresh the views.

Returns:

nothing; updates the db and reloads the courses table

Return type:

None

Notes:

if no row is selected, it just returns quietly (no popup).

_on_delete_selected_instructor() → None[source]

deletes the selected instructor after a quick confirm. if i accept, the instructor is removed and any courses pointing to them become unassigned, then i refresh the ui.

Returns:

nothing; updates db and reloads the instructors table

Return type:

None

Notes:

if no row is selected, it just exits quietly (no dialog).

_on_delete_selected_student() → None[source]

deletes the currently selected student after a quick confirm. if i say yes, it removes the student and any course registrations tied to them, then refreshes the views so the table matches reality.

Returns:

nothing; mutates the db and reloads the tables

Return type:

None

Notes:

selection is taken from the students tree; if nothing is selected, it just exits quietly.

_on_export_csv(kind: str) → None[source]

exports the current rows to a csv file. i pick which dataset based on kind (students/instructors/courses), suggest a timestamped filename, and write headers+rows.

Parameters:

kind (str) – which table to export; accepts ‘students’, ‘instructors’, or ‘courses’

Returns:

nothing; writes a csv to the chosen path if you confirm the dialog

Return type:

None

Raises:

none directly; any file i/o error gets caught and shown as an error dialog

Notes:

values are stringified on write so the csv stays simple and consistent.

_on_load_json() → None[source]

loads a json snapshot (from our own exporter) and upserts everything into the db: students, instructors, courses, and their relationships. duplicates are fine, i either skip or update so it doesn’t crash on existing data.

Returns:

nothing; writes into the db and refreshes the ui

Return type:

None

Raises:

none here; i catch insert errors and move on (very lab-friendly)

Notes:

instructor can be missing on a course; registrations are re-linked by calling repo.register_student.

_on_register_student() → None[source]

registers a student into a course using the two entry fields. i check both ids exist in the form, normalize them, and ask the repo to link. if repo complains, i just show the message.

Returns:

nothing; updates db and refreshes all tables

Return type:

None

Raises:

none directly here; any repo exception is caught and shown as an error dialog

Notes:

if either id is missing i bail early with a friendly error; success shows a tiny info popup.

_on_save_json() → None[source]

builds python objects from the current db rows (students, instructors, courses), reconnects relationships (instructor on course + enrolled students), then dumps everything to a single json file using the existing persistence helpers.

Returns:

nothing; just writes a json file if you pick a path

Return type:

None

Raises:

none here; any file/db hiccup is handled and shown via a dialog

Notes:

i query courses twice on purpose: first to create them, then to attach instructor; registrations come from the REGISTRATION table and get mapped to course objects.

_on_select_course_row(_evt=None) → None[source]

when i click a course row, this copies the values into the form (id, name, instructor id). if instructor shows as “—”, i leave the field empty.

Parameters:

_evt (object or None) – optional treeview event object from the binding (unused here)

Returns:

nothing; just updates the three entry widgets

Return type:

None

_on_select_instructor_row(_evt=None) → None[source]

when i click an instructor row, this copies the row values into the form so editing is quick (id, name, age, email). if nothing is selected, it just returns.

Parameters:

_evt (object or None) – optional treeview event object from the binding (unused here)

Returns:

nothing; it just updates the entry widgets

Return type:

None

_on_select_student_row(_evt=None) → None[source]

when i click a row in the students table, this copies the values into the form so i can edit fast (id, name, age, email). if nothing is selected, it just does nothing.

Parameters:

_evt (object or None) – optional tk event from the treeview binding (not really used)

Returns:

nothing; just updates the entry widgets

Return type:

None

_q_courses(q: str, limit_scope: bool) → List[Dict][source]

gets courses with their optional instructor and enrolled students. if i pass q, i filter by course id/name, instructor id, or student id using lower+like.

Parameters:

  • q (str) – search text to narrow results; empty means no filter

  • limit_scope (bool) – kept for future tweaks (not used now)

Returns:

list of dicts: course_id, course_name, instructor (or ‘—‘), students (comma-separated)

Return type:

list[dict]

Notes:

i coalesce nulls and space out the comma list for readability.

_q_instructors(q: str, limit_scope: bool) → List[Dict][source]

fetches instructors with a simple join to list the courses they own. if q is given, i filter by id/name/email or course id using like (lowercased).

Parameters:

  • q (str) – search text to narrow results; empty means show all

  • limit_scope (bool) – placeholder for future behavior; not used now

Returns:

list of dicts with instructor_id, name, age, email, courses (comma-separated)

Return type:

list[dict]

Notes:

i coalesce nulls and pretty-print the courses with a space after commas.

_q_students(q: str, limit_scope: bool) → List[Dict][source]

runs the students query and returns rows as dicts. if i pass a text q, i do a simple like filter over id/name/email or registered course id. keeping sql readable.

Parameters:

  • q (str) – search text to filter by; empty string means no filtering

  • limit_scope (bool) – kept for future tweaks (not used now, i just keep the signature stable)

Returns:

list of student dicts with keys: student_id, name, age, email, courses (comma-separated)

Return type:

list[dict]

Notes:

i coalesce nulls and also pretty-print the courses with “, “ instead of raw commas.

_refresh_all_views() → None[source]

refreshes all the main tables/trees (students, instructors, courses, records). i call this after inserts/updates/deletes so the ui always shows the latest db state.

Returns:

nothing; it just re-populates the treeviews

Return type:

None

_refresh_course_tree() → None[source]

pulls fresh course rows from the db and refills the courses treeview (id, name, instructor, students). simple reload so the ui stays current.

Returns:

nothing; just repopulates the courses table

Return type:

None

_refresh_instructor_tree() → None[source]

pulls fresh instructor rows from the db and refills the instructors treeview. keeps the ui in sync after any add/update/delete.

Returns:

nothing; just repopulates the table

Return type:

None

_refresh_records_views() → None[source]

reloads the three records/search tables with no filters (students, instructors, courses). basically a full reset so the dashboard shows everything again.

Returns:

nothing; it just repopulates all three trees

Return type:

None

_refresh_student_tree() → None[source]

reloads the students table from the db and pushes rows into the treeview. simple pull → fill flow so the ui always shows current data.

Returns:

nothing; just repopulates the students tree

Return type:

None

_setup_theme() → None[source]

sets up a small ttk theme so the ui stays readable and a bit “ours”. i try ‘clam’ if it exists, set base fonts/colors, and tweak tables/buttons (zebra rows, bold headings, a light accent).

Returns:

nothing; just mutates ttk styles + window look

Return type:

None

Notes:

choices are practical for lab machines; if the theme isn’t there it’s ok, it silently falls back.
